title: Event Registry d.o.o.

author: Gregor Leban, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Hi everyone, my name is Gregor.
Ann is mentioned.
I'm the CEO of event registry.
So we had.

Also, spin off from Europe Stephen Institute and actually from the same group AI lab and solves all just mentioned our basically our people are also experts in AI, more specifically in text understanding and information extraction from text.

We started in 2017 when we got some funding from Google and currently our top customers include companies like Bloomberg, IBM, Deloitte, Ernst and Young, and several universities mainly work International.
We are almost non present in Slovenia.
So what do we actually do?
So we could say that we are encyclopedia of world events.
So what we do is we collect news content that is published globally.
We collect about 800,000 articles daily and that's just the starting point.
What we do is actually extract information from those articles.
So we try to extract what are the events mentioned in those articles.
And for all the events that we identified, we then try to.
Determine what's the core information about this event.
So where the events happen, when, who was involved in the event, and so on.
And then we store this information and provide a API and web access to this data.
So we operate with texts and text is basically non trivial to process.
Maybe it's easy for humans to understand, but for machines it's quite difficult.
When you get basically a text, one of the things that you need to do is you need to understand who and what is being mentioned in the text.
In this case an article, you need to know if it mentions the word Apple.
Does this mean Apple the fruit or Apple the company?
And similarly, if it mentions the word Paris, you need to know you know if this is Paris Hilton or is this Paris, the French city, or some US city and so on.
So there's a lot of work that needs to be done if you need to understand the basics of what's actually mentioned in the text that we collect, and that's one of the systems that we have.
Which is basically able to ingest the document and then annotate the document with the words.
Basically, with the meanings of the words that are mentioned in the documents.
Additionally, we also have ability to process the content cross lingually.

This means that whenever you have a document, let's say in Arabic, in Chinese in Japanese or any other language, what you want to do is you want to map the meanings of the words to the same knowledge base into the same items in the knowledge base.

So this means that if you find an article in Arabic which mentions Apple, the company you want to tag it with the same kind of concept in the knowledge base as you take it when you have a Chinese article or English or so on and so on.
So that's one of the things that are quite crucial in the whole system.
Another thing that.
Do is we try to reduce the content overload so we all know that we live in the data in the age of big data.
So as I mentioned, we collect about 700,000 articles per day.
And if you look at this data, you see that it's not highly unique, so.
Example in this.
This is an example from.
I don't know a year ago.
If you look articles from those days, you would actually see that a lot of content is quite repetitive.
So basically you get a group of articles that talk about that Game of Thrones.

Basically, the series ended and then at the same day at the same day there was a lot of news mentions that Nikki Louder died and similarly had I don't know information that Ford laid off thousands of employees.
So you have a lot of articles that talk about the same thing that happened and that's what we actually call events.
So an event.
Is simply a collection of news articles that talk about the same thing that happened.
And this is the way how we try to reduce this kind of content overload so that we try to group content into the same units which we call events.

So again, event is a collection of news articles that discuss the same thing that happened, and our assumption is that if something relevant happens in the world, they will actually be multiple news sources reporting about this thing.
So it should be very rare that that something quite significant happened and then you only have 1 media source reporting about this.
Typically we have 10s or even hundreds of source sources that report about this.
And once you have this, once you have this redundancy then we can create something like we show here.
So basically this is like a card.
That we can show about an event that happened.
So this is the title of the event.
In this case, it's Deutsche Bank officers that were rated in a money laundering probe.
This event happened On this date, so this is something that we extract from the articles that we have found.
This is the location of the event and we can see here that we almost got 700 articles about this same event and then we also have a kind of a semantic fingerprint of this event.
So in this case you can see it's about Deutsche Bank.
It's about Frankfurt money laundering, Panama Papers, Germany, tax haven and so on.
And then you have a short summary and then if you as a user say OK, this is something that's interesting to me.
I want to get more details about this event.
Then of course you can open the.
And and then you get a whole page where you can actually get all the articles about this event.
So you can probably not see here.
But here we have a list of English articles.
One of the things that the system can automatically do is also it can find articles about the same in other languages.
So before there were English articles, now we have here Japanese, but you can see here that you have also Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, French and so on and so on.
So we have all these other coverage in other languages of the same event.
And this is done completely automatically, so there is no manual human that needs to be involved in this process.
Here are some few examples of the event, so an example of an event where, let's say there was an earthquake that we found in Anchorage.
Happen on Friday 30th November 2018.

Then you have the let's say Oscar that's happened this week or last week and then you also have this, let's say plane that skidded off the runway in Istanbul and you can see that always you have the same kind of template.
You have the date you have the location, the coverage you have some reality.
You also have the sentiment this associated with the event and so on.
So just the short like as I mentioned, So what we do is we try to extract as much information as possible about these events.
So we try to extract the location of the event, the date domain entities.
So who and what the event is about the categories title in the snippet and that's what you can.
What you get when you see that kind of cards.
And just briefly mention some of the use cases how you can use this, how it's used in practice.

So one of the cases is basically doing a search on a broad topic, so assuming that you want to do some media monitoring on some topic of interest, what you can do is you can define a topic page which I'll show in the next slide, let's say in this case you can say I'm interested in fourth Industrial Revolution, or I'm interested in latest developments in Bio Genomics and so on.
And what you can do is you can then create.
Something that's called a topic page.
In this case it's 14 dash revolution.
This is the definition of the topic page.
You simply specify what are the things that should be mentioned or are likely to be mentioned in the articles and events about this topic, and you can also say how relevant that thing is.
So this is about AI, robotics, autonomous cars and so on.
And then as a result you can.
At a list of events, an articles that best match this topic.
In this case, is the list of articles.

Secondly, what you can do is you can do brand monitoring so companies often need to know how their brand is perceived in the media or how their competitors are perceived in the media or how they compare to their competitors.
So this is used by companies like like Bloomberg and others.
What you can do is you can say, OK, let's let's take Chevron and let's take Statoil.
They are two different companies and we want to compare how they how they compare in the media.
So this is a tech cloud which basically shows dimensions over, I think 2 years periods of the Chevron and Statoil.

This is something that typically they include then in the consulting companies they include in the reports and they say OK, this this brand is more mentioned in the context of stocks and bonds and so on.
Where is another companies more mentioned in the terms of renewable energy and so on, and thinking more in the future.
And similarly, you can also visualize it in a different way.
When instead of the top keywords, basically you display top entities, so these are the things that we can annotate.
Actually in those articles and events.
In 3rd use case would be risk management, so companies always need to think about the supply chains.

Basically how the companies which provide them some some inputs might deliver the content to them or might not deliver because of the problems in the supply chains, or maybe a different kind of social economic issues that different countries might have.
And here you have an.
So you have different options how you can get results.
So one of the options is that you can simply use categorization.
So we have a number of predefined categories.
One of those is for example natural disasters and you can.

Easily get a list of events related to natural disasters, so assuming that you have some companies, let's say in the Middle East, or let's say I don't know in China, you can simply create a filter that says show me the natural disasters happening in China, and then you would get a list of things that we have identified from the media.
In another case of this risk, management would be like sociopolitical events where you can say, OK, I want to know about different strikes, terrorism, political incidents and corruptions, and so on.
Then again, you can get a list of results which major topic and you can see that in some cases you even get just mentions in Arabic, which you might not even understand.
But due to this kind of semantic tags that you get for each event in each article, you can then understand what the event is about.

And the last thing is also like observing the current events and not only the individual events, but also how these events interact, interrelate with each other because events are typically related to some past events and likely some future events, and I'll show some.
Example, so for example, this is the coronavirus event.
Which we know that had.
And you have a list of articles that cover this event.
But what you can do is also instead of beside like seeing how the event was covered.
The media and who reported about this event.

You can do is also you can display a timeline and these are all the previous events which were related to Corona virus and all the future events after that event that we have looked at which basically give you like a timeline of the whole development of the whole topic.
So this is X.
Really the last slide.
So if you have any questions, I'll be happy.
Thank you very much.
